awd_titl_txt: Travel: Student Travel Grant for the 2023 International Conference on Cryptology and Network Security (CANS 2023)
awd_abstract_narration:
The International Conference on Cryptology and Network Security (CANS) is a well-recognized international forum for presenting research in the field of security and cryptography that has served the research community. CANS 2023 will take place in Augusta, Georgia from October 31 to November 2. CANS provides an opportunity for students to be exposed to cutting edge solutions to computer security problems, as well as the cryptologic theory that underlies secure computing systems.

This grant allows 20 students to participate in CANS who would not have been able to participate otherwise. Participation in CANS provides the opportunity for the students to learn about the latest technological trends and research directions related to computer and network security.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

por.por_cntn:
This grant helped to provide funding for student travel support for attending the 22nd International Conference on Cryptology and Network Security (CANS), which was held at Augusta University in Augusta, Georgia, from October 31st to November 2nd, 2023. CANS is a premier forum for presenting research in the field of security and cryptography, including both theoretical and practical aspects of the design and implementation of cryptographic systems. This grant helped enhance student participation in research, broaden the audience of the conference, and provide an opportunity for students to learn about important concepts and recent advances in the field of cryptography.

The students were chosen for funding by a selection committee consisting of four members: Alexander Schwarzmann (Augusta University), Edward Tremel (AU), Vlad Kolesnikov (Georgia Tech), and Jing Deng (UNC Greensboro). The selection committee funded 11 students that met the selection criteria, including 3 students from underrepresented groups (female). The results of the student travel grant awards were reported to the business meeting of the conference.

This grant allowed 11 students to participate in the CANS conference who would not have been able to participate otherwise. Attending the conference allowed these students to students learn about advances in cryptography and security, which improved their knowledge base in the discipline and will hopefully inspire them to produce their own research in these fields. It also made them better prepared for future careers in cybersecurity in either industry or academia.


Last Modified: 06/28/2024
Modified by: Edward J Tremel
